Headline: Assailants set fire to two water tanker trucks in Muqur, Badghis, Afghanistan
Description: Assailants set fire to two water tanker trucks in Muqur, Badghis, Afghanistan, killing one driver, wounding two others and destroying the two trucks. No group claims responsibility, although the Taliban is widely believed to be responsible.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2018. ID. 200806110020

Headline: Militants blow up a section of a water pipeline
Description: Militants blow up a section of a water pipeline in Baghdad, Iraq. The explosion tears an 18-inch hole in the pipe that carries drinking water to Baghdad's Adhamiyah, Rusafa, and Karrada districts. No casualties are reported and no group claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2018. ID. 200810300021

Headline: Assailants attempt to damage a water pump outside of a refugee camp in Darfur
Description: At the Hassa Hissa camp near Zalinjay, Gharb Darfur, Sudan, ten assailants attempt to damage a water pump outside of an internally displaced person (IDP) camp. The armed men open fire on the pump and set fire to the pump and five generators. The assailants fight with occupants of the camp, wounding one. No group claims responsibility, although it is widely believed the Janjaweed Militia is responsible.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2018. ID. 200812010034

Headline: Village attacked in Ethiopian water pipe conflict
Description: Ethiopian Somalis attack a Borana community in the Oromia region over ownership of a new borehole being drilled on the disputed border between them. Three people from the Oromia village of Kafa are killed and seven injured, and the entire community driven from their homes. The drilling rig is destroyed, as well.

Headline: Drought and water inequities spark killings India
Description: A family in Madhya Pradesh state in India is killed by a small mob for illegally drawing water from a municipal pipe. Others run to collect water for themselves before the pipe runs out. Drought and inequality in water distribution lead to increasing conflict in the region. Indian media report more than 50 violent clashes in the state capital, Bhopal during May alone. Since January, 12 people are killed and even more injured.

Headline: Man killed in Mumbai protest over water cuts
Description: Police clash with hundreds of Mumbai residents protesting water cuts. One man is killed and a dozen others injured. Mumbai authorities are forced to ration supplies after the worst monsoon season in decades.

Headline: North Korea dam release kills six in South Korea
Description: Without previous warning, North Korea releases 40 million cubic meters of water from the Hwanggag dam, causing a flash flood on the Imjin River. In South Korea, at least 6 fisherman and campers are drowned. North Korea claims that the water had to be urgently released and promises to warn the South of future releases. South Korea fears that North Korea could use the water of the dam as a weapon during a violent conflict.

Headline: Police use ammunition against demonstrators protesting water shortages in Somaliland
Description: Police use live ammunition against demonstrators in the southern part of Hargeisa. Residents of Ahmed Dhagah district in Hargeisa, mostly women and children, take to the streets protesting severe water shortages.

Headline: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan threaten to contaminate local water resources
Description: The Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) threatens to contaminate local water resources in a letter faxed to the Directorate of Military Lands and Cantonments in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. The letter stated that the TTP had procured 200 liters of a poisonous material that would be used to contaminate water sources and reservoirs in the wards falling under Rawalpindi Cantonment Board (RCB) and Chaklala Cantonment Board (CCB) limits unless the Army stopped military operations in South Waziristan.

Headline: Water trucks contaminated with cyanide
Description: Water trucks supplying water to U.S. military forces in Afghanistan are contaminated with cyanide.

Headline: Bomb damages water treatment plant, leaving community without water
Description: A bomb planted at a water treatment plant explodes damaging the plant and wounding two police officers in Villavicencio, Colombia. The town is left without water supply.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Energy and Water Department attacked by suicide bombers, killing six and injuring dozens
Description: Six civilians die and approximately 30 others are injured when two suicide bombers attack the building of the Energy and Water Department in Khost City, Afghanistan.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: During kidnapping by Taliban, water tank destroyed
Description: A group of four employees of a construction company in Kunar province, Afghanistan are kidnapped by the Taliban. The kidnappers also destroy a water tank during the attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: One dead in South Yemen protest over water cuts
Description: At least one Yemeni is killed and three wounded in clashes with police in Aden in southern Yemen over the cutting off of water.

Headline: A bomb placed at water station kills six, including five children, in Khost City, Afghanistan
Description: A remote control bomb placed at a water distribution station detonates, killing six, including five children, in Khost City, Afghanistan.

Headline: Hydroelectric construction company hires armed private security to quell local opposition in Guatemala
Description: In the Q'anjob'al and Chug Territory of northern Huehuetenango, Guatemala, three proposed hydroelectric projects supported by the national government incite strong local opposition. The hydroelectric construction company hires armed private security personnel to quell confrontations and acts of vandalism.

Headline: Assailants detonate an improvised explosive device targeting a civilian water truck
Description: On Sunday morning, in Marawara, Konar, Afghanistan, assailants detonate an improvised explosive device targeting a civilian water truck, wounding four civilians and damaging one truck. No group claims responsibility.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2018. ID. 200903070013

Headline: Homemade bomb is planted inside the gates of the Metro Water District
Description: On Wednesday, ordnance experts defuse a homemade bomb discovered by employees  planted on a bench inside the gates of the Metro Water District, a government-run building at Cotabato, Philippines. No damage or casualties occur. No group claims of responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2018. ID. 200904290018

Headline: An improvised explosive device attached to a water tanker explodes
Description: An improvised explosive device attached to a water tanker in the al-Mahawii district of the Babel province explodes, wounding the driver. The blast causes severe damage to the tanker. No one claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2018. ID. 200912110015

Headline: Fighting in Pakistan over irrigation water
Description: More than 100 are dead and scores injured following two weeks of tribal fighting in Parachinar in the Kurram region of Pakistan, near the Afghanistan border. The conflict over irrigation water began as the Shalozan Tangi tribe cut off supplies to the Shalozan tribe. Some report that al Qaeda may be involved; others claim sectarian violence is to blame as one group is Sunni Muslim and the other Shiite.
